title: Ten years on the Myer float still rankles
text:
Why are some shareholders willing to forgive and forget when companies fail to achieve profit guidance, while other shareholders take them to court to recover losses?

In the case of Myer, shareholders are still rankled over the circumstances behind the department store chain's $2.3 billion initial public offering in November 2009.

Myer shareholders are still rankled over the retailer's $2.3 billion IPO 10 years ago, overseen by then chief executive Bernie Brookes. Josh Robenstone

Private equity firms Blum Capital and TPG Capital, led by Ben Gray, sold all their shares in the retailer for a profit of $1.5 billion, or almost six times their original equity investment, after talking up its growth prospects.

Two weeks after the float, the Australian Taxation Office sought court orders to freeze TPG's bank accounts in an attempt to recover $678 million in tax and penalties, only to discover $1.5 billion in profits had been transferred to tax havens in Luxembourg and the Cayman Islands.

Six months later, Myer chief executive Bernie Brookes was forced to cut prospectus sales growth guidance and admitted the float could have been better timed.
description: Myer shareholders are still rankled over the department store chain's $2.3 billion float 10 years ago.
